description: The percentage of taxable profit relative to total revenue, calculated as (Taxable Profit / Total Revenue) * 100. Higher values indicate greater profitability, while unusually high values compared to industry peers could suggest underreported revenue.

The actual tax rate paid on operating profit, calculated as (Final Tax Due / Operating Profit) * 100. Significantly lower rates than industry peers may indicate aggressive tax planning or potential non-compliance.
The nominal tax rate before credits, calculated as (Tax Liability / Taxable Profit) * 100. This represents the standard tax rate that should apply based on taxable profit.
The difference between statutory and effective tax rates, showing how tax credits reduce the tax burden. Unusually large differences may indicate excessive tax credit usage.
The ratio of VAT deducted to VAT collected, calculated as Total VAT Deducted / Total VAT Collected. Ratios significantly higher than industry norms may indicate over-claiming of input VAT.
The percentage of revenue spent on labor costs, calculated as (Labor Costs / Revenue) * 100. Unusually low values may indicate underreported labor costs or off-the-books employment.
The average revenue generated per employee, calculated as Revenue / Employee Count. Significantly higher values than industry peers may indicate underreporting of employee numbers.
The percentage of tax liability offset by tax credits, calculated as (Tax Credits Claimed / Tax Liability) * 100. High values indicate aggressive use of tax credits to reduce tax liability.

The percentage difference between income reported for income tax and VAT purposes, calculated as |(Total Revenue / Total Annual Sales) - 1| * 100. Values above 5% indicate potential inconsistent reporting.
The ratio of theoretical tax to actual tax paid, calculated as (Theoretical Tax / Actual Tax Paid). Higher values indicate more effective tax reduction strategies.

The normalized difference between financial accounting profit and taxable income, calculated as (|Gross Profit - Operating Profit| / |Gross Profit|) * 100. Larger gaps indicate greater divergence between financial and tax reporting.
The percentage of tax filings submitted on time, calculated as (Number of On-Time Filings / Total Filings) × 100%. Lower rates indicate poor filing compliance behavior.
The percentage of tax obligations paid on time, calculated as (On-Time Payments Amount / Total Payment Obligations) × 100%. Lower rates indicate poor payment compliance behavior.

The percentage difference between income reported for income tax and VAT purposes, calculated as |(Total Revenue / Total Annual Sales) - 1| * 100. Values above 5% indicate potential inconsistent reporting.
